citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the facility's medical/treatment room, there were several bottles, vials and infusion bags of prescribed and over the
counter medications with expired dates on the labels. All medications intended to be used as therapy for regulated
animals should have current expiration dates to provide the best possible care. All expired medications and medical
products should be properly discarded immediately.
To be corrected by: June 14, 2024

Records for animals at hand containing required information on acquisition, addition and/or disposition of these, were
incomplete at the time of inspection. There were no records or information on the recent acquisition of one red kangaroo.
Also, records with information on the disposition of a tufted capuchin and a red kangaroo were not available for
inspection. The licensee shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose information on
purchased or otherwise acquired animals, and that are in his or her possession/control. The Record of Animals on Hand
(APHIS Form 7019; other than dogs and cats) and Record of Acquisition, Disposition, or Transport of Animals (APHIS
Form 7020) are forms which may be used by the licensee to keep and maintain the information required by federal
regulations. The licensee needs to obtain/document the required information on all recently acquired animals as soon as
possible.
To be corrected by: June 7, 2023

On January 20, 2024, approximately at 12:16pm, during a scheduled interaction session a tufted capuchin called
"Romeo" scratched two young members of the public; scratches to a index finger, and a hand respectively. Handling of an
animal shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma/injury to the
public or the animal. The facility must ensure handling of animals is performed by seasoned and experienced
handlers/employees.
To be corrected by: Already mitigated with employee training and procedures review by the time of this inspection.

The perimeter fence next to the chimpanzee's main enclosure was observed to be only 27 inches from the enclosure's
easternmost wall. The facility's perimeter must be of sufficient distance from the outside wall or fence of the primary
enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and outside the perimeter fence. The facility
must adjust the distance to mora than 3 feet; perimeter fences less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure
must be approved by the Administrator.
To be corrected by: June 7, 2023

Several welded wire gaps containing sharp points were observed at the Colobus monkey's main enclosure. Housing
facilities for nonhuman primates (NHP's) must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury and
contain the animals securely. Primary enclosures for all NHP's at the facility must be free of jagged edges or sharp points
that might injure the animals. The damaged welded wire/gaps must be repaired/replaced to prevent injuries and/or
escape, and to ensure the enclosure is structurally sound.
To be corrected by: June 7, 2023

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility's environment enhancement plan to promote the psychological well-being of nonhuman primates was
inspected and found to be incomplete and outdated; the Colobus monkey and squirrel monkey species were not included
and/or mentioned in the written plan; environmental enrichment in enclosures was deficient. Facilities must maintain an
appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of all nonhuman
primate species in the premises. The plan must be in accordance with the currently accepted professional standards as
cited in this section of the Animal Welfare Act; appropriate professional journals or reference guides, and as directed by
the attending veterinarian. In order to ensure adequate overall welfare for all nonhuman primate species, the plan must be
reviewed, updated and approved by the facility's attending veterinarian.
To be corrected by: June 7, 2023

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Evidence of a cockroach infestation was identified in the main facility's food prep/kitchen area. Many cockroach droppings
(feces) were deposited in top of plastic food containers where nonhuman primate (monkey) biscuits were being stored.
Also, an excessive amount of flies were in direct contact with food been prepared, knives. utensils and surfaces.
Furthermore, the kitchen doors were completely open to outside areas, and non-functional old fly traps were observed. In
order to to prevent food contamination, promote the health and well-being of all nonhuman primates, a safe and effective
program for the control of insects, and other pests must be established and maintained.
To be corrected by: May 21, 2023

The African crested porcupine main enclosure exhibited several large dug holes at the concrete base/welded wire
junction. Also, in the jaguar enclosure by the medical clinic, protruding construction screws were observed on several
resting/walking wood planks posing a potential injury hazard for the animals. . Furthermore, in the jaguar enclosure by the
stork's enclosure, excessive rust and damaged metal sliding doors were observed having several sharp metal and in need
of repair. Housing facilities for all regulated animals shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to
protect the animals from injury while containing the animals. To prevent potential injury and to safely contain the regulated
animals, all three enclosures must be repaired by removing potential injury hazards immediately.
To be corrected by: May 14, 2024

The red kangaroo's primary enclosure was observed to be attached to the main perimeter fence of the facility. The
facility's perimeter fence must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical
contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. The facility must
separate the kangaroo's main enclosure from the perimeter fence by establishing another panel/side to the main
enclosure, with a minimum distance of 3 feet (from the perimeter fence).
To be corrected by: June 7, 2023

Evidence of a cockroach infestation was identified in the main facility's food prep/kitchen area. Many cockroach droppings
(feces) were deposited in top of plastic food containers where biscuits were being stored. Also, an excessive amount of
flies were in direct contact with food been prepared, knives. utensils and surfaces. Furthermore, the kitchen doors were
completely open to outside areas, and non-functional old fly traps were observed. In order to to prevent food
contamination and to minimize disease hazards to regulated animals, a safe and effective program for the control of
insects, and other pests must be established and maintained.
To be corrected by: May 21, 2023

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
An appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds was not
available for inspection. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending
veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations of the Animal Welfare Act (AWA) and with currently accepted
professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. The facility must develop a plan
as required by the AWA, and ensure the plan is available for inspection upon request by APHIS personnel.
To be corrected by: June 7, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with four facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST
Andrew Jones, Assistant Director n
